git_treebuilder_insert.description: Add or update an entry to the builder
git_treebuilder_insert.argline: git_tree_entry **entry_out, git_treebuilder *bld, const char *filename, const git_oid *id, unsigned int attributes
git_treebuilder_insert.comments:
Insert a new entry for `filename` in the builder with the
 given attributes.

 if an entry named `filename` already exists, its attributes
 will be updated with the given ones.

 The optional pointer `entry_out` can be used to retrieve a
 pointer to the newly created/updated entry.

args.name: entry_out
args.comment: Pointer to store the entry (optional)

args.name: bld
args.comment: Tree builder

args.name: filename
args.comment: Filename of the entry

args.name: id
args.comment: SHA1 oid of the entry

args.name: attributes
args.comment: Folder attributes of the entry

git_tag_close.comments:
This is a wrapper around git_object_close()

 IMPORTANT:
 It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop
 using a tag. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

args.name: tag
args.comment: the tag to close

git_tag_close.rawComments:
Close an open tag

 This is a wrapper around git_object_close()

 IMPORTANT:
 It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop
 using a tag. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

 @param tag the tag to close

git_treebuilder_write.description: Write the contents of the tree builder as a tree object
git_treebuilder_write.comments:
The tree builder will be written to the given `repo`, and
 it's identifying SHA1 hash will be stored in the `oid`
 pointer.

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the written OID

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the object

args.name: bld
args.comment: Tree builder to write

git_tree_entry_attributes.description: Get the UNIX file attributes of a tree entry

args.name: entry
args.comment: a tree entry

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where lives the tag

args.name: tag_name
args.comment: Name of the tag to be deleted;  this name is validated for consistency.

git_commit_parentcount.description: Get the number of parents of this commit

args.name: commit
args.comment: a previously loaded commit.

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if valid; GIT_ENOTOID on failure.

git_oid_mkstr.description: Parse a hex formatted object id into a git_oid.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: str
args.comment: input hex string; must be pointing at the start of         the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes         needed for an oid encoded in hex (40 bytes).

git_reference_create_oid.description: Create a new object id reference.
git_reference_create_oid.argline: git_reference **ref_out, git_repository *repo, const char *name, const git_oid *id
git_reference_create_oid.comments:
The reference will be created in the repository and written
 to the disk.

 This reference is owned by the repository and shall not
 be free'd by the user.

args.name: ref_out
args.comment: Pointer to the newly created reference

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where that reference will live

args.name: name
args.comment: The name of the reference

args.name: id
args.comment: The object id pointed to by the reference.

git_tree_lookup.description: Lookup a tree object from the repository.

args.name: tree
args.comment: pointer to the looked up tree

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the tree.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the tree to locate.

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if the database opened; otherwise an error          code describing why the open was not possible.

git_odb_open.description: Create a new object database and automatically add the two default backends:
git_odb_open.comments:
- git_odb_backend_loose: read and write loose object files
		from disk, assuming `objects_dir` as the Objects folder

	- git_odb_backend_pack: read objects from packfiles,
		assuming `objects_dir` as the Objects folder which
		contains a 'pack/' folder with the corresponding data

args.name: out
args.comment: location to store the database pointer, if opened.             Set to NULL if the open failed.

args.name: objects_dir
args.comment: path of the backends' "objects" directory.

git_odb_open.rawComments:
Create a new object database and automatically add
 the two default backends:

	- git_odb_backend_loose: read and write loose object files
		from disk, assuming `objects_dir` as the Objects folder

	- git_odb_backend_pack: read objects from packfiles,
		assuming `objects_dir` as the Objects folder which
		contains a 'pack/' folder with the corresponding data

 @param out location to store the database pointer, if opened.
            Set to NULL if the open failed.
 @param objects_dir path of the backends' "objects" directory.
 @return GIT_SUCCESS if the database opened; otherwise an error
         code describing why the open was not possible.

git_reference_set_target.description: Set the symbolic target of a reference.
git_reference_set_target.comments:
The reference must be a symbolic reference, otherwise
 this method will fail.

 The reference will be automatically updated in
 memory and on disk.

args.name: ref
args.comment: The reference

args.name: target
args.comment: The new target for the reference

git_commit_message.description: Get the full message of a commit.

args.name: commit
args.comment: a previously loaded commit.

git_treebuilder_create.comments:
The tree builder can be used to create or modify
 trees in memory and write them as tree objects to the
 database.

 If the `source` parameter is not NULL, the tree builder
 will be initialized with the entries of the given tree.

 If the `source` parameter is NULL, the tree builder will
 have no entries and will have to be filled manually.

args.name: builder_p
args.comment: Pointer where to store the tree builder

args.name: source
args.comment: Source tree to initialize the builder (optional)

git_treebuilder_create.rawComments:
Create a new tree builder.

 The tree builder can be used to create or modify
 trees in memory and write them as tree objects to the
 database.

 If the `source` parameter is not NULL, the tree builder
 will be initialized with the entries of the given tree.

 If the `source` parameter is NULL, the tree builder will
 have no entries and will have to be filled manually.

 @param builder_p Pointer where to store the tree builder
 @param source Source tree to initialize the builder (optional)
 @return 0 on sucess; error code otherwise

return.comment: positive or negative timezone offset, in minutes from UTC

git_commit_time_offset.description: Get the commit timezone offset (i.e. committer's preferred timezone) of a commit.

args.name: commit
args.comment: a previously loaded commit.

git_revwalk_free.description: Free a revision walker previously allocated.

args.name: walk
args.comment: traversal handle to close.  If NULL nothing occurs.

git_revwalk_free.rawComments:
Free a revision walker previously allocated.

 @param walk traversal handle to close.  If NULL nothing occurs.

git_tree_close.comments:
This is a wrapper around git_object_close()

 IMPORTANT:
 It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop
 using a tree. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

args.name: tree
args.comment: the tree to close

git_tree_close.rawComments:
Close an open tree

 This is a wrapper around git_object_close()

 IMPORTANT:
 It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop
 using a tree. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

 @param tree the tree to close

git_revwalk_new.description: Allocate a new revision walker to iterate through a repo.
git_revwalk_new.comments:
This revision walker uses a custom memory pool and an internal
 commit cache, so it is relatively expensive to allocate.

 For maximum performance, this revision walker should be
 reused for different walks.

 This revision walker is *not* thread safe: it may only be
 used to walk a repository on a single thread; however,
 it is possible to have several revision walkers in
 several different threads walking the same repository.

args.name: walker
args.comment: pointer to the new revision walker

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to walk through

git_revwalk_new.rawComments:
Allocate a new revision walker to iterate through a repo.

 This revision walker uses a custom memory pool and an internal
 commit cache, so it is relatively expensive to allocate.

 For maximum performance, this revision walker should be
 reused for different walks.

 This revision walker is *not* thread safe: it may only be
 used to walk a repository on a single thread; however,
 it is possible to have several revision walkers in
 several different threads walking the same repository.

 @param walker pointer to the new revision walker
 @param repo the repo to walk through
 @return 0 on success; error code otherwise

return.comment: the new sig, NULL on out of memory

git_signature_new.description: Create a new action signature. The signature must be freed manually or using git_signature_free
git_signature_new.argline: const char *name, const char *email, git_time_t time, int offset

args.name: name
args.comment: name of the person

args.name: time
args.comment: time when the action happened

args.name: offset
args.comment: timezone offset in minutes for the time

args.name: a
args.comment: first oid structure.

args.name: b
args.comment: second oid structure.

return.comment: a copy of sig, NULL on out of memory

git_signature_dup.description: Create a copy of an existing signature.
git_signature_dup.comments: All internal strings are also duplicated.

args.name: sig
args.comment: signature to duplicated

return.comment: 0 on success; error code if the index could not be opened

git_repository_index.description: Get the Index file of a Git repository
git_repository_index.comments:
This is a cheap operation; the index is only opened on the first call,
 and subsequent calls only retrieve the previous pointer.

args.name: index
args.comment: Pointer where to store the index

args.name: repo
args.comment: a repository object

git_tag_name.description: Get the name of a tag

return.comment: the pointer; NULL if the blob has no contents

git_blob_rawcontent.description: Get a read-only buffer with the raw content of a blob.
git_blob_rawcontent.comments:
A pointer to the raw content of a blob is returned;
 this pointer is owned internally by the object and shall
 not be free'd. The pointer may be invalidated at a later
 time.

args.name: blob
args.comment: pointer to the blob

return.comment: true if the type represents a valid loose object type,  false otherwise.

git_object_typeisloose.description: Determine if the given git_otype is a valid loose object type.

args.name: type
args.comment: object type to test.

git_revwalk_repository.description: Return the repository on which this walker is operating.

args.name: walk
args.comment: the revision walker

git_reference_type.description: Get the type of a reference

args.name: ref
args.comment: The reference

git_odb_add_alternate.description: Add a custom backend to an existing Object DB; this backend will work as an alternate.
git_odb_add_alternate.comments:
Alternate backends are always checked for objects *after*
 all the main backends have been exhausted.

 Writing is disabled on alternate backends.

 Read <odb_backends.h> for more information.

 @paramm backend pointer to a git_odb_backend instance

args.name: odb
args.comment: database to add the backend to

git_strarray_free.description: @file git2/common.h @brief Git common platform definitions @defgroup git_common Git common platform definitions @ingroup Git @{

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

git_index_append.description: Add (append) an index entry from a file in disk
git_index_append.comments:
A new entry will always be inserted into the index;
 if the index already contains an entry for such
 path, the old entry will **not** be replaced.

 The file `path` must be relative to the repository's
 working folder and must be readable.

 This method will fail in bare index instances.

args.name: index
args.comment: an existing index object

args.name: path
args.comment: filename to add

args.name: stage
args.comment: stage for the entry

git_tag_create_o.description: Create a new tag in the repository from an existing `git_object` instance
git_tag_create_o.argline: git_oid *oid, git_repository *repo, const char *tag_name, const git_object *target, const git_signature *tagger, const char *message
git_tag_create_o.comments:
This method replaces the `target` and `target_type`
 paremeters of `git_tag_create` by a single instance
 of a `const git_object *`, which is assured to be
 a proper object in the ODB and hence will create
 a valid tag

 @see git_tag_create
git_tag_create_o.rawComments:
Create a new tag in the repository from an existing
 `git_object` instance

 This method replaces the `target` and `target_type`
 paremeters of `git_tag_create` by a single instance
 of a `const git_object *`, which is assured to be
 a proper object in the ODB and hence will create
 a valid tag

 @see git_tag_create

git_revwalk_hide.description: Mark a commit (and its ancestors) uninteresting for the output.

git_reference_create_symbolic.argline: git_reference **ref_out, git_repository *repo, const char *name, const char *target
git_reference_create_symbolic.comments:
The reference will be created in the repository and written
 to the disk.

 This reference is owned by the repository and shall not
 be free'd by the user.

args.name: ref_out
args.comment: Pointer to the newly created reference

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where that reference will live

args.name: name
args.comment: The name of the reference

args.name: target
args.comment: The target of the reference

git_object_id.description: Get the id (SHA1) of a repository object

args.name: obj
args.comment: the repository object

git_odb_hash.description: Determine the object-ID (sha1 hash) of a data buffer
git_odb_hash.argline: git_oid *id, const void *data, size_t len, git_otype type
git_odb_hash.comments:
The resulting SHA-1 OID will the itentifier for the data
 buffer as if the data buffer it were to written to the ODB.

args.name: id
args.comment: the resulting object-ID.

args.name: data
args.comment: data to hash

args.name: len
args.comment: size of the data

args.name: type
args.comment: of the data to hash

git_tag_create_frombuffer.description: Create a new tag in the repository from a buffer

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the OID of the newly created tag

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the tag

args.name: buffer
args.comment: Raw tag data

git_object_lookup.description: Lookup a reference to one of the objects in a repostory.
git_object_lookup.argline: git_object **object, git_repository *repo, const git_oid *id, git_otype type
git_object_lookup.comments:
The generated reference is owned by the repository and
 should be closed with the `git_object_close` method
 instead of free'd manually.

 The 'type' parameter must match the type of the object
 in the odb; the method will fail otherwise.
 The special value 'GIT_OBJ_ANY' may be passed to let
 the method guess the object's type.

args.name: object
args.comment: pointer to the looked-up object

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repository to look up the object

args.name: id
args.comment: the unique identifier for the object

args.name: type
args.comment: the type of the object

return.comment: a pointer to the oid if available, NULL otherwise

git_reference_oid.description: Get the OID pointed to by a reference.
git_reference_oid.comments: Only available if the reference is direct (i.e. not symbolic)

args.name: ref
args.comment: The reference

args.name: os
args.comment: a `git_oid_shorten` instance

git_oid_shorten_free.rawComments:
Free an OID shortener instance

 @param os a `git_oid_shorten` instance

git_odb_object_data.description: Return the data of an ODB object
git_odb_object_data.comments:
This is the uncompressed, raw data as read from the ODB,
 without the leading header.

 This pointer is owned by the object and shall not be free'd.

args.name: object
args.comment: the object

__attribute__.description: Declare a public TLS symbol exported for application use.
__attribute__.rawComments: Declare a public TLS symbol exported for application use.

git_treebuilder_filter.description: Filter the entries in the tree
git_treebuilder_filter.comments:
The `filter` callback will be called for each entry
 in the tree with a pointer to the entry and the
 provided `payload`: if the callback returns 1, the
 entry will be filtered (removed from the builder).

args.name: bld
args.comment: Tree builder

args.name: filter
args.comment: Callback to filter entries

git_treebuilder_filter.rawComments:
Filter the entries in the tree

 The `filter` callback will be called for each entry
 in the tree with a pointer to the entry and the
 provided `payload`: if the callback returns 1, the
 entry will be filtered (removed from the builder).

 @param bld Tree builder
 @param filter Callback to filter entries

return.comment: a pointer to the object db

args.name: entry
args.comment: a tree entry

git_tag_list.description: Fill a list with all the tags in the Repository
git_tag_list.comments:
The string array will be filled with the names of the
 matching tags; these values are owned by the user and
 should be free'd manually when no longer needed, using
 `git_strarray_free`.

 @param array Pointer to a git_strarray structure where
		the tag names will be stored

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to find the tags

args.name: repo

args.name: path
args.comment: file from which the blob will be created,  relative to the repository's working dir

return.comment: the tree entry; NULL if not found

args.name: db
args.comment: database pointer to close.  If NULL no action is taken.

Close an open object database.

 @param db database pointer to close.  If NULL no action is taken.

git_reference_create_oid_f.argline: git_reference **ref_out, git_repository *repo, const char *name, const git_oid *id
git_reference_create_oid_f.comments:
If the new reference isn't an object id one, any pointers to the
 old reference become invalid.

 The reference will be created in the repository and written
 to the disk.

 This reference is owned by the repository and shall not
 be free'd by the user.

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where that reference will live

args.name: name
args.comment: The name of the reference

args.name: id
args.comment: The object id pointed to by the reference.

args.comment: The reference

git_commit_create_ov.sig: git_oid *::git_repository *::const char *::const git_signature *::const git_signature *::const char *::const git_tree *::int::
git_commit_create_ov.description: Create a new commit in the repository using `git_object` instances and a variable argument list.
git_commit_create_ov.argline: git_oid *oid, git_repository *repo, const char *update_ref, const git_signature *author, const git_signature *committer, const char *message, const git_tree *tree, int parent_count, ...
git_commit_create_ov.comments:
The `tree_oid` paremeter now takes a instance
 of `const git_tree *`.

 The parents for the commit are specified as a variable
 list of pointers to `const git_commit *`. Note that this
 is a convenience method which may not be safe to export
 for certain languages or compilers

 All other parameters remain the same

 @see git_commit_create
git_commit_create_ov.rawComments:
Create a new commit in the repository using `git_object`
 instances and a variable argument list.

 The `tree_oid` paremeter now takes a instance
 of `const git_tree *`.

 The parents for the commit are specified as a variable
 list of pointers to `const git_commit *`. Note that this
 is a convenience method which may not be safe to export
 for certain languages or compilers

 All other parameters remain the same

 @see git_commit_create

git_commit_create_o.sig: git_oid *::git_repository *::const char *::const git_signature *::const git_signature *::const char *::const git_tree *::int::const git_commit *
git_commit_create_o.description: Create a new commit in the repository using `git_object` instances as parameters.
git_commit_create_o.argline: git_oid *oid, git_repository *repo, const char *update_ref, const git_signature *author, const git_signature *committer, const char *message, const git_tree *tree, int parent_count, const git_commit *parents[]
git_commit_create_o.comments:
The `tree_oid` and `parent_oids` paremeters now take a instance
 of `git_tree` and `git_commit`, respectively.

 All other parameters remain the same

 @see git_commit_create
git_commit_create_o.rawComments:
Create a new commit in the repository using `git_object`
 instances as parameters.

 The `tree_oid` and `parent_oids` paremeters now take a instance
 of `git_tree` and `git_commit`, respectively.

 All other parameters remain the same

 @see git_commit_create

git_tag_create_fo.description: Create a new tag in the repository from an existing `git_object` instance and overwrite an already existing tag reference, if any.
git_tag_create_fo.argline: git_oid *oid, git_repository *repo, const char *tag_name, const git_object *target, const git_signature *tagger, const char *message
git_tag_create_fo.comments:
This method replaces the `target` and `target_type`
 paremeters of `git_tag_create_f` by a single instance
 of a `const git_object *`, which is assured to be
 a proper object in the ODB and hence will create
 a valid tag

 @see git_tag_create_f
git_tag_create_fo.rawComments:
Create a new tag in the repository from an existing
 `git_object` instance and overwrite an already existing
 tag reference, if any.

 This method replaces the `target` and `target_type`
 paremeters of `git_tag_create_f` by a single instance
 of a `const git_object *`, which is assured to be
 a proper object in the ODB and hence will create
 a valid tag

 @see git_tag_create_f

git_treebuilder_clear.description: Clear all the entires in the builder

args.name: bld
args.comment: Builder to clear

git_treebuilder_clear.rawComments:
Clear all the entires in the builder

 @param bld Builder to clear

return.comment: a pointer to the entry; NULL if out of bounds

git_index_get.description: Get a pointer to one of the entries in the index
git_index_get.comments:
This entry can be modified, and the changes will be written
 back to disk on the next write() call.

args.name: index
args.comment: an existing index object

args.name: n
args.comment: the position of the entry

git_index_open_inrepo.description: Open the Index inside the git repository pointed by 'repo'.

args.name: index
args.comment: the pointer for the new index

args.name: repo
args.comment: the git repo which owns the index

return.comment: 0 on success; error code otherwise.  A tag object is written to the ODB, and a proper reference  is written in the /refs/tags folder, pointing to it

git_tag_create.description: Create a new tag in the repository from an OID
git_tag_create.argline: git_oid *oid, git_repository *repo, const char *tag_name, const git_oid *target, git_otype target_type, const git_signature *tagger, const char *message

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the OID of the  newly created tag

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the tag

args.name: tag_name
args.comment: Name for the tag; this name is validated  for consistency. It should also not conflict with an  already existing tag name

args.name: target
args.comment: OID to which this tag points; note that no  validation is done on this OID. Use the _o version of this  method to assure a proper object is being tagged

args.name: target_type
args.comment: Type of the tagged OID; note that no  validation is performed here either

args.name: tagger
args.comment: Signature of the tagger for this tag, and   of the tagging time

args.name: message
args.comment: Full message for this tag

git_repository_free.comments:
Note that after a repository is free'd, all the objects it has spawned
 will still exist until they are manually closed by the user
 with `git_object_close`, but accessing any of the attributes of
 an object without a backing repository will result in undefined
 behavior

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository handle to close. If NULL nothing occurs.

git_repository_free.rawComments:
Free a previously allocated repository

 Note that after a repository is free'd, all the objects it has spawned
 will still exist until they are manually closed by the user
 with `git_object_close`, but accessing any of the attributes of
 an object without a backing repository will result in undefined
 behavior

 @param repo repository handle to close. If NULL nothing occurs.

git_oid_cpy.description: Copy an oid from one structure to another.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: src
args.comment: oid structure to copy from.

return.comment: pointer to the entry; NULL if not found

git_treebuilder_get.description: Get an entry from the builder from its filename
git_treebuilder_get.comments:
The returned entry is owned by the builder and should
 not be freed manually.

args.name: bld
args.comment: Tree builder

args.name: filename
args.comment: Name of the entry

return.comment: the minimal length to uniquely identify all OIDs   added so far to the set; or an error code (<0) if an   error occurs.

git_oid_shorten_add.description: Add a new OID to set of shortened OIDs and calculate the minimal length to uniquely identify all the OIDs in the set.
git_oid_shorten_add.comments:
The OID is expected to be a 40-char hexadecimal string.
 The OID is owned by the user and will not be modified
 or freed.

 For performance reasons, there is a hard-limit of how many
 OIDs can be added to a single set (around ~22000, assuming
 a mostly randomized distribution), which should be enough
 for any kind of program, and keeps the algorithm fast and
 memory-efficient.

 Attempting to add more than those OIDs will result in a
 GIT_ENOMEM error

args.name: os
args.comment: a `git_oid_shorten` instance

args.name: text_oid
args.comment: an OID in text form

git_oid_shorten_add.rawComments:
Add a new OID to set of shortened OIDs and calculate
 the minimal length to uniquely identify all the OIDs in
 the set.

 The OID is expected to be a 40-char hexadecimal string.
 The OID is owned by the user and will not be modified
 or freed.

 For performance reasons, there is a hard-limit of how many
 OIDs can be added to a single set (around ~22000, assuming
 a mostly randomized distribution), which should be enough
 for any kind of program, and keeps the algorithm fast and
 memory-efficient.

 Attempting to add more than those OIDs will result in a
 GIT_ENOMEM error

 @param os a `git_oid_shorten` instance
 @param text_oid an OID in text form
 @return the minimal length to uniquely identify all OIDs
		added so far to the set; or an error code (<0) if an
		error occurs.

git_blob_close.comments:
This is a wrapper around git_object_close()

 IMPORTANT:
 It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop
 using a blob. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

args.name: blob
args.comment: the blob to close

git_blob_close.rawComments:
Close an open blob

 This is a wrapper around git_object_close()

 IMPORTANT:
 It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop
 using a blob. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

 @param blob the blob to close

return.comment: GIT_SUCCESS if the next commit was found;  GIT_EREVWALKOVER if there are no commits left to iterate

git_revwalk_next.description: Get the next commit from the revision walk.
git_revwalk_next.comments:
The initial call to this method is *not* blocking when
 iterating through a repo with a time-sorting mode.

 Iterating with Topological or inverted modes makes the initial
 call blocking to preprocess the commit list, but this block should be
 mostly unnoticeable on most repositories (topological preprocessing
 times at 0.3s on the git.git repo).

 The revision walker is reset when the walk is over.

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the oid of the next commit

args.name: walk
args.comment: the walker to pop the commit from.

git_index_clear.description: Clear the contents (all the entries) of an index object. This clears the index object in memory; changes must be manually written to disk for them to take effect.

args.name: index
args.comment: an existing index object

git_index_clear.rawComments:
Clear the contents (all the entries) of an index object.
 This clears the index object in memory; changes must be manually
 written to disk for them to take effect.

 @param index an existing index object

return.comment: NULL if the repository is bare; absolute path to the working directory otherwise.

git_repository_workdir.comments: If the repository is bare, there is no working directory and NULL we be returned.

git_revwalk_push.description: Mark a commit to start traversal from.
git_revwalk_push.comments:
The given OID must belong to a commit on the walked
 repository.

 The given commit will be used as one of the roots
 when starting the revision walk. At least one commit
 must be pushed the repository before a walk can
 be started.

 @param walker the walker being used for the traversal.

args.name: oid
args.comment: the oid of the commit to start from.

git_commit_create.sig: git_oid *::git_repository *::const char *::const git_signature *::const git_signature *::const char *::const git_oid *::int::const git_oid *

return.comment: 0 on success; error code otherwise  The created commit will be written to the Object Database and  the given reference will be updated to point to it

git_commit_create.description: Create a new commit in the repository
git_commit_create.argline: git_oid *oid, git_repository *repo, const char *update_ref, const git_signature *author, const git_signature *committer, const char *message, const git_oid *tree_oid, int parent_count, const git_oid *parent_oids[]
git_commit_create.comments:
@param parents Array of pointers to parent OIDs for this commit.
	Note that no validation is performed on these OIDs. Use the _o
	variants of this method to assure that are parents for the commit
	are proper objects.

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the OID of the  newly created commit

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the commit

args.name: update_ref
args.comment: If not NULL, name of the reference that  will be updated to point to this commit. If the reference  is not direct, it will be resolved to a direct reference.  Use "HEAD" to update the HEAD of the current branch and  make it point to this commit

args.name: author
args.comment: Signature representing the author and the authory  time of this commit

args.name: committer
args.comment: Signature representing the committer and the   commit time of this commit

args.name: message
args.comment: Full message for this commit

args.name: tree_oid
args.comment: Object ID of the tree for this commit. Note that   no validation is performed on this OID. Use the _o variants of   this method to assure a proper tree is passed to the commit.

args.name: parent_count
args.comment: Number of parents for this commit

args.comment: identity of the blob to locate.

Before the ODB can be used for read/writing, a custom database
 backend must be manually added using `git_odb_add_backend()`

args.name: out
args.comment: location to store the database pointer, if opened.             Set to NULL if the open failed.

git_odb_new.rawComments:
Create a new object database with no backends.

 Before the ODB can be used for read/writing, a custom database
 backend must be manually added using `git_odb_add_backend()`

 @param out location to store the database pointer, if opened.
            Set to NULL if the open failed.
 @return GIT_SUCCESS if the database was created; otherwise an error
         code describing why the open was not possible.

git_treebuilder_free.comments:
This will clear all the entries and free to builder.
 Failing to free the builder after you're done using it
 will result in a memory leak

args.name: bld
args.comment: Builder to free

git_treebuilder_free.rawComments:
Free a tree builder

 This will clear all the entries and free to builder.
 Failing to free the builder after you're done using it
 will result in a memory leak

 @param bld Builder to free

git_tree_create_fromindex.description: Write a tree to the ODB from the index file
git_tree_create_fromindex.comments:
This method will scan the index and write a representation
 of its current state back to disk; it recursively creates
 tree objects for each of the subtrees stored in the index,
 but only returns the OID of the root tree. This is the OID
 that can be used e.g. to create a commit.

 The index instance cannot be bare, and needs to be associated
 to an existing repository.

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the written tree

args.name: index
args.comment: Index to write

git_tree_create_fromindex.rawComments:
Write a tree to the ODB from the index file

 This method will scan the index and write a representation
 of its current state back to disk; it recursively creates
 tree objects for each of the subtrees stored in the index,
 but only returns the OID of the root tree. This is the OID
 that can be used e.g. to create a commit.

 The index instance cannot be bare, and needs to be associated
 to an existing repository.

 @param oid Pointer where to store the written tree
 @param index Index to write
 @return 0 on success; error code otherwise

git_commit_create_v.sig: git_oid *::git_repository *::const char *::const git_signature *::const git_signature *::const char *::const git_oid *::int::
git_commit_create_v.description: Create a new commit in the repository using a variable argument list.
git_commit_create_v.argline: git_oid *oid, git_repository *repo, const char *update_ref, const git_signature *author, const git_signature *committer, const char *message, const git_oid *tree_oid, int parent_count, ...
git_commit_create_v.comments:
The parents for the commit are specified as a variable
 list of pointers to `const git_oid *`. Note that this
 is a convenience method which may not be safe to export
 for certain languages or compilers

 All other parameters remain the same

 @see git_commit_create
git_commit_create_v.rawComments:
Create a new commit in the repository using
 a variable argument list.

 The parents for the commit are specified as a variable
 list of pointers to `const git_oid *`. Note that this
 is a convenience method which may not be safe to export
 for certain languages or compilers

 All other parameters remain the same

 @see git_commit_create

git_reference_lookup.description: Lookup a reference by its name in a repository.
git_reference_lookup.comments:
The generated reference is owned by the repository and
 should not be freed by the user.

args.name: reference_out
args.comment: pointer to the looked-up reference

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repository to look up the reference

args.name: name
args.comment: the long name for the reference (e.g. HEAD, ref/heads/master, refs/tags/v0.1.0, ...)

return.comment: 0 if the stream was created; error code otherwise

git_odb_open_rstream.description: Open a stream to read an object from the ODB
git_odb_open_rstream.comments:
Note that most backends do *not* support streaming reads
 because they store their objects as compressed/delta'ed blobs.

 It's recommended to use `git_odb_read` instead, which is
 assured to work on all backends.

 The returned stream will be of type `GIT_STREAM_RDONLY` and
 will have the following methods:

		- stream->read: read `n` bytes from the stream
		- stream->free: free the stream

 The stream must always be free'd or will leak memory.

 @see git_odb_stream

args.name: stream
args.comment: pointer where to store the stream

args.name: db
args.comment: object database where the stream will read from

args.name: oid
args.comment: oid of the object the stream will read from

git_commit_committer.description: Get the committer of a commit.

args.name: commit
args.comment: a previously loaded commit.

git_reference_resolve.comments:
Thie method iteratively peels a symbolic reference
 until it resolves to a direct reference to an OID.

 If a direct reference is passed as an argument,
 that reference is returned immediately

args.name: resolved_ref
args.comment: Pointer to the peeled reference

args.name: ref
args.comment: The reference

return.comment: the full name for the ref

git_reference_create_symbolic_f.description: Create a new symbolic reference, overwriting an existing one with the same name, if it exists.
git_reference_create_symbolic_f.argline: git_reference **ref_out, git_repository *repo, const char *name, const char *target
git_reference_create_symbolic_f.comments:
If the new reference isn't a symbolic one, any pointers to the old
 reference become invalid.

 The reference will be created in the repository and written
 to the disk.

 This reference is owned by the repository and shall not
 be free'd by the user.

args.name: ref_out
args.comment: Pointer to the newly created reference

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where that reference will live

args.name: name
args.comment: The name of the reference

args.name: target
args.comment: The target of the reference

args.comment: The reference

git_reference_packall.description: Pack all the loose references in the repository
git_reference_packall.comments:
This method will load into the cache all the loose
 references on the repository and update the
 `packed-refs` file with them.

 Once the `packed-refs` file has been written properly,
 the loose references will be removed from disk.

 WARNING: calling this method may invalidate any existing
 references previously loaded on the cache.

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where the loose refs will be packed

git_reference_packall.rawComments:
Pack all the loose references in the repository

 This method will load into the cache all the loose
 references on the repository and update the
 `packed-refs` file with them.

 Once the `packed-refs` file has been written properly,
 the loose references will be removed from disk.

 WARNING: calling this method may invalidate any existing
 references previously loaded on the cache.

 @param repo Repository where the loose refs will be packed
 @return 0 on success; error code otherwise

return.comment: a string explaining the error code

git_strerror.comments:
Get a string description for a given error code.
 NOTE: This method will be eventually deprecated in favor
 of the new `git_lasterror`.

args.name: num
args.comment: The error code to explain

return.comment: 0 on success, otherwise an error code

args.name: position
args.comment: position of the entry to remove

git_oid_pathfmt.description:
Format a git_oid into a loose-object path string.

The resulting string is "aa/...", where "aa" is the first two hex digitis of the oid and "..." is the remaining 38 digits.

args.name: str
args.comment: output hex string; must be pointing at the start of         the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes         needed for an oid encoded in hex (41 bytes).  Only the         oid digits are written; a '\\0' terminator must be added         by the caller if it is required.

args.name: oid
args.comment: oid structure to format.

git_oid_pathfmt.rawComments:
Format a git_oid into a loose-object path string.

The resulting string is "aa/...", where "aa" is the first two hex digitis of the oid and "..." is the remaining 38 digits. @param str output hex string; must be pointing at the start of the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes needed for an oid encoded in hex (41 bytes). Only the oid digits are written; a '\\0' terminator must be added by the caller if it is required. @param oid oid structure to format.

args.name: blob
args.comment: pointer to the blob

git_revwalk_sorting.comments: Changing the sorting mode resets the walker.

args.comment: the walker being used for the traversal.

args.name: sort_mode
args.comment: combination of GIT_SORT_XXX flags

git_commit_close.comments:
This is a wrapper around git_object_close()

 IMPORTANT:
 It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop
 using a commit. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

Close an open commit

 This is a wrapper around git_object_close()

 IMPORTANT:
 It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop
 using a commit. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

 @param commit the commit to close

git_reference_rename_f.description: Rename an existing reference, overwriting an existing one with the same name, if it exists.
git_reference_rename_f.comments:
This method works for both direct and symbolic references.
 The new name will be checked for validity and may be
 modified into a normalized form.

 The refernece will be immediately renamed in-memory
 and on disk.
git_reference_rename_f.rawComments:
Rename an existing reference, overwriting an existing one with the
 same name, if it exists.

 This method works for both direct and symbolic references.
 The new name will be checked for validity and may be
 modified into a normalized form.

 The refernece will be immediately renamed in-memory
 and on disk.

return.comment: the tree entry; NULL if not found

git_lasterror.description: Return a detailed error string with the latest error that occurred in the library.

args.comment: the position of the parent (from 0 to `parentcount`)

git_index_read.description: Update the contents of an existing index object in memory by reading from the hard disk.

args.name: index
args.comment: an existing index object

git_odb_read_header.description: Read the header of an object from the database, without reading its full contents.
git_odb_read_header.comments:
The header includes the length and the type of an object.

 Note that most backends do not support reading only the header
 of an object, so the whole object will be read and then the
 header will be returned.

 @return
 - GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read;
 - GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database.

args.name: len_p
args.comment: pointer where to store the length

args.name: type_p
args.comment: pointer where to store the type

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the object to read.

git_tag_target_oid.description: Get the OID of the tagged object of a tag

git_repository_open.comments:
The 'path' argument must point to an existing git repository
 folder, e.g.

		/path/to/my_repo/.git/	(normal repository)
							objects/
							index
							HEAD

		/path/to/bare_repo/		(bare repository)
						objects/
						index
						HEAD

	The method will automatically detect if 'path' is a normal
	or bare repository or fail is 'path' is neither.

args.name: repository
args.comment: pointer to the repo which will be opened

args.name: path
args.comment: the path to the repository

git_repository_open.rawComments:
Open a git repository.

 The 'path' argument must point to an existing git repository
 folder, e.g.

		/path/to/my_repo/.git/	(normal repository)
							objects/
							index
							HEAD

		/path/to/bare_repo/		(bare repository)
						objects/
						index
						HEAD

	The method will automatically detect if 'path' is a normal
	or bare repository or fail is 'path' is neither.

 @param repository pointer to the repo which will be opened
 @param path the path to the repository
 @return 0 on success; error code otherwise

args.name: sig
args.comment: signature to free

git_signature_free.rawComments:
Free an existing signature

 @param sig signature to free

return.comment: absolute path to the git directory

git_repository_path.description: Get the normalized path to the git repository.

args.name: repo
args.comment: a repository object

git_commit_author.description: Get the author of a commit.

args.name: commit
args.comment: a previously loaded commit.

git_odb_write.description: Write an object directly into the ODB
git_odb_write.argline: git_oid *oid, git_odb *odb, const void *data, size_t len, git_otype type
git_odb_write.comments:
This method writes a full object straight into the ODB.
 For most cases, it is preferred to write objects through a write
 stream, which is both faster and less memory intensive, specially
 for big objects.

 This method is provided for compatibility with custom backends
 which are not able to support streaming writes

args.name: oid
args.comment: pointer to store the OID result of the write

args.name: odb
args.comment: object database where to store the object

args.name: data
args.comment: buffer with the data to storr

args.name: len
args.comment: size of the buffer

args.name: type
args.comment: type of the data to store

git_reference_listall.description: Fill a list with all the references that can be found in a repository.
git_reference_listall.comments:
The listed references may be filtered by type, or using
 a bitwise OR of several types. Use the magic value
 `GIT_REF_LISTALL` to obtain all references, including
 packed ones.

 The string array will be filled with the names of all
 references; these values are owned by the user and
 should be free'd manually when no longer needed, using
 `git_strarray_free`.

args.name: array
args.comment: Pointer to a git_strarray structure where   the reference names will be stored

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to find the refs

args.name: list_flags
args.comment: Filtering flags for the reference   listing.

git_reference_listall.rawComments:
Fill a list with all the references that can be found
 in a repository.

 The listed references may be filtered by type, or using
 a bitwise OR of several types. Use the magic value
 `GIT_REF_LISTALL` to obtain all references, including
 packed ones.

 The string array will be filled with the names of all
 references; these values are owned by the user and
 should be free'd manually when no longer needed, using
 `git_strarray_free`.

 @param array Pointer to a git_strarray structure where
		the reference names will be stored
 @param repo Repository where to find the refs
 @param list_flags Filtering flags for the reference
		listing.
 @return 0 on success; error code otherwise

return.comment: 0 if the stream was created; error code otherwise

git_odb_open_wstream.description: Open a stream to write an object into the ODB
git_odb_open_wstream.argline: git_odb_stream **stream, git_odb *db, size_t size, git_otype type
git_odb_open_wstream.comments:
The type and final length of the object must be specified
 when opening the stream.

 The returned stream will be of type `GIT_STREAM_WRONLY` and
 will have the following methods:

		- stream->write: write `n` bytes into the stream
		- stream->finalize_write: close the stream and store the object in
			the odb
		- stream->free: free the stream

 The streaming write won't be effective until `stream->finalize_write`
 is called and returns without an error

 The stream must always be free'd or will leak memory.

 @see git_odb_stream

args.name: stream
args.comment: pointer where to store the stream

args.name: db
args.comment: object database where the stream will write

args.name: size
args.comment: final size of the object that will be written

args.name: type
args.comment: type of the object that will be written

git_index_open_bare.description: Create a new Git index object as a memory representation of the Git index file in 'index_path', without a repository to back it.
git_index_open_bare.comments:
Since there is no ODB behind this index, any Index methods
 which rely on the ODB (e.g. index_add) will fail with the
 GIT_EBAREINDEX error code.

args.name: index
args.comment: the pointer for the new index

args.name: index_path
args.comment: the path to the index file in disk

git_odb_read.description: Read an object from the database.
git_odb_read.comments:
This method queries all avaiable ODB backends
 trying to read the given OID.

 The returned object is reference counted and
 internally cached, so it should be closed
 by the user once it's no longer in use.

 @return
 - GIT_SUCCESS if the object was read;
 - GIT_ENOTFOUND if the object is not in the database.

args.name: out
args.comment: pointer where to store the read object

args.name: db
args.comment: database to search for the object in.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the object to read.

git_tag_type.description: Get the type of a tag's tagged object

git_reference_set_oid.description: Set the OID target of a reference.
git_reference_set_oid.comments:
The reference must be a direct reference, otherwise
 this method will fail.

 The reference will be automatically updated in
 memory and on disk.

 @param target The new target OID for the reference

args.name: ref
args.comment: The reference

git_tree_entry_name.description: Get the filename of a tree entry

args.name: entry
args.comment: a tree entry

return.comment: size in bytes of the object

git_object__size.description: Get the size in bytes for the structure which acts as an in-memory representation of any given object type.
git_object__size.comments:
For all the core types, this would the equivalent
 of calling `sizeof(git_commit)` if the core types
 were not opaque on the external API.

args.name: type
args.comment: object type to get its size

git_object__size.rawComments:
Get the size in bytes for the structure which
 acts as an in-memory representation of any given
 object type.

 For all the core types, this would the equivalent
 of calling `sizeof(git_commit)` if the core types
 were not opaque on the external API.

 @param type object type to get its size
 @return size in bytes of the object

git_commit_lookup.description: Lookup a commit object from a repository.

args.name: commit
args.comment: pointer to the looked up commit

args.name: repo
args.comment: the repo to use when locating the commit.

args.name: id
args.comment: identity of the commit to locate.  If the object is         an annotated tag it will be peeled back to the commit.

git_reference_listcb.description: List all the references in the repository, calling a custom callback for each one.
git_reference_listcb.argline: git_repository *repo, unsigned int list_flags, int (*callback)(const char *, void *), void *payload
git_reference_listcb.comments:
The listed references may be filtered by type, or using
 a bitwise OR of several types. Use the magic value
 `GIT_REF_LISTALL` to obtain all references, including
 packed ones.

 The `callback` function will be called for each of the references
 in the repository, and will receive the name of the reference and
 the `payload` value passed to this method.

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to find the refs

args.name: list_flags
args.comment: Filtering flags for the reference   listing.

args.name: callback
args.comment: Function which will be called for every listed ref

args.name: payload
args.comment: Additional data to pass to the callback

return.comment: the repository who owns this object

git_object_owner.description: Get the repository that owns this object

args.name: obj
args.comment: the object

return.comment: the short message of a commit

git_commit_message_short.description: Get the short (one line) message of a commit.

args.name: commit
args.comment: a previously loaded commit.

git_oid_fmt.description: Format a git_oid into a hex string.

args.name: str
args.comment: output hex string; must be pointing at the start of         the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes         needed for an oid encoded in hex (40 bytes).  Only the         oid digits are written; a '\\0' terminator must be added         by the caller if it is required.

args.name: oid
args.comment: oid structure to format.

git_oid_fmt.rawComments:
Format a git_oid into a hex string.
 @param str output hex string; must be pointing at the start of
        the hex sequence and have at least the number of bytes
        needed for an oid encoded in hex (40 bytes).  Only the
        oid digits are written; a '\\0' terminator must be added
        by the caller if it is required.
 @param oid oid structure to format.

return.comment: 1 if the repository is empty, 0 if it isn't, error code  if the repository is corrupted

git_repository_is_empty.description: Check if a repository is empty
git_repository_is_empty.comments:
An empty repository has just been initialized and contains
 no commits.

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repo to test

return.comment: the id of tree pointed to by commit.

git_commit_tree_oid.description: Get the id of the tree pointed to by a commit. This differs from `git_commit_tree` in that no attempts are made to fetch an object from the ODB.

args.name: commit
args.comment: a previously loaded commit.

git_reference_delete.comments:
This method works for both direct and symbolic references.

 The reference will be immediately removed on disk and from
 memory. The given reference pointer will no longer be valid.
git_reference_delete.rawComments:
Delete an existing reference

 This method works for both direct and symbolic references.

 The reference will be immediately removed on disk and from
 memory. The given reference pointer will no longer be valid.

git_odb_object_type.description: Return the type of an ODB object

args.name: object
args.comment: the object

git_odb_object_size.description: Return the size of an ODB object
git_odb_object_size.comments:
This is the real size of the `data` buffer, not the
 actual size of the object.

args.name: object
args.comment: the object

git_odb_object_close.comments:
This method must always be called once a `git_odb_object` is no
 longer needed, otherwise memory will leak.

args.name: object
args.comment: object to close

git_odb_object_close.rawComments:
Close an ODB object

 This method must always be called once a `git_odb_object` is no
 longer needed, otherwise memory will leak.

 @param object object to close

git_blob_create_frombuffer.description: Write an in-memory buffer to the ODB as a blob
git_blob_create_frombuffer.argline: git_oid *oid, git_repository *repo, const void *buffer, size_t len

args.name: oid
args.comment: return the oid of the written blob

args.name: repo
args.comment: repository where to blob will be written

args.name: buffer
args.comment: data to be written into the blob

args.name: len
args.comment: length of the data

return.comment: the out buffer pointer, assuming no input parameter          errors, otherwise a pointer to an empty string.

git_oid_to_string.description:
Format a git_oid into a buffer as a hex format c-string.

If the buffer is smaller than GIT_OID_HEXSZ+1, then the resulting oid c-string will be truncated to n-1 characters. If there are any input parameter errors (out == NULL, n == 0, oid == NULL), then a pointer to an empty string is returned, so that the return value can always be printed.

args.name: out
args.comment: the buffer into which the oid string is output.

args.name: n
args.comment: the size of the out buffer.

args.name: oid
args.comment: the oid structure to format.

return.comment: integer of count of current entries

git_index_entrycount.description: Get the count of entries currently in the index

args.name: index
args.comment: an existing index object

git_reference_rename.comments:
This method works for both direct and symbolic references.
 The new name will be checked for validity and may be
 modified into a normalized form.

 The refernece will be immediately renamed in-memory
 and on disk.
git_reference_rename.rawComments:
Rename an existing reference

 This method works for both direct and symbolic references.
 The new name will be checked for validity and may be
 modified into a normalized form.

 The refernece will be immediately renamed in-memory
 and on disk.

git_oid_mkraw.description: Copy an already raw oid into a git_oid structure.

args.name: out
args.comment: oid structure the result is written into.

args.name: raw
args.comment: the raw input bytes to be copied.

git_revwalk_reset.description: Reset the revision walker for reuse.
git_revwalk_reset.comments:
This will clear all the pushed and hidden commits, and
 leave the walker in a blank state (just like at
 creation) ready to receive new commit pushes and
 start a new walk.

 The revision walk is automatically reset when a walk
 is over.

args.name: walker
args.comment: handle to reset.

git_revwalk_reset.rawComments:
Reset the revision walker for reuse.

 This will clear all the pushed and hidden commits, and
 leave the walker in a blank state (just like at
 creation) ready to receive new commit pushes and
 start a new walk.

 The revision walk is automatically reset when a walk
 is over.

 @param walker handle to reset.

git_object_close.comments:
This method instructs the library to close an existing
 object; note that git_objects are owned and cached by the repository
 so the object may or may not be freed after this library call,
 depending on how agressive is the caching mechanism used
 by the repository.

 IMPORTANT:
 It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop using
 an object. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

args.name: object
args.comment: the object to close

git_object_close.rawComments:
Close an open object

 This method instructs the library to close an existing
 object; note that git_objects are owned and cached by the repository
 so the object may or may not be freed after this library call,
 depending on how agressive is the caching mechanism used
 by the repository.

 IMPORTANT:
 It *is* necessary to call this method when you stop using
 an object. Failure to do so will cause a memory leak.

 @param object the object to close

return.comment: 0 on success; error code otherwise.  A tag object is written to the ODB, and a proper reference  is written in the /refs/tags folder, pointing to it

git_tag_create_f.description: Create a new tag in the repository from an OID and overwrite an already existing tag reference, if any.
git_tag_create_f.argline: git_oid *oid, git_repository *repo, const char *tag_name, const git_oid *target, git_otype target_type, const git_signature *tagger, const char *message

args.name: oid
args.comment: Pointer where to store the OID of the  newly created tag

args.name: repo
args.comment: Repository where to store the tag

args.name: tag_name
args.comment: Name for the tag; this name is validated  for consistency.

args.name: target
args.comment: OID to which this tag points; note that no  validation is done on this OID. Use the _fo version of this  method to assure a proper object is being tagged

args.name: target_type
args.comment: Type of the tagged OID; note that no  validation is performed here either

args.name: tagger
args.comment: Signature of the tagger for this tag, and   of the tagging time

args.name: message
args.comment: Full message for this tag

types.block:
/** raw binary formatted id */
unsigned char id[GIT_OID_RAWSZ];

GIT_OBJ_ANY = -2,		/**< Object can be any of the following */
GIT_OBJ_BAD = -1,       /**< Object is invalid. */
GIT_OBJ__EXT1 = 0,      /**< Reserved for future use. */
GIT_OBJ_COMMIT = 1,     /**< A commit object. */
GIT_OBJ_TREE = 2,       /**< A tree (directory listing) object. */
GIT_OBJ_BLOB = 3,       /**< A file revision object. */
GIT_OBJ_TAG = 4,        /**< An annotated tag object. */
GIT_OBJ__EXT2 = 5,      /**< Reserved for future use. */
GIT_OBJ_OFS_DELTA = 6,  /**< A delta, base is given by an offset. */
GIT_OBJ_REF_DELTA = 7,  /**< A delta, base is given by object id. */

GIT_REF_INVALID = 0, /** Invalid reference */
GIT_REF_OID = 1, /** A reference which points at an object id */
GIT_REF_SYMBOLIC = 2, /** A reference which points at another reference */
GIT_REF_PACKED = 4,
GIT_REF_HAS_PEEL = 8,
GIT_REF_LISTALL = GIT_REF_OID|GIT_REF_SYMBOLIC|GIT_REF_PACKED,

char *name; /** full name of the author */
char *email; /** email of the author */
git_time when; /** time when the action happened */

git_time_t time; /** time in seconds from epoch */
int offset; /** timezone offset, in minutes */

meta.brief: Git error handling routines and variables

meta.defgroup: git_object Git revision object management routines

meta.brief: Git blob load and write routines
meta.defgroup: git_blob Git blob load and write routines
git_commit Git commit parsing, formatting routines

meta.brief: Git index parsing and manipulation routines
meta.defgroup: git_index Git index parsing and manipulation routines
git_tree Git tree parsing, loading routines
